title: Gap between number of foreign doctors and UK trained doctors doubles in a year, new figures from GMC show
text:
The gap between the number of foreign and British-trained doctors starting practice in the UK has more than doubled in the last year, new figures show.

Around 9,100 medics who were trained abroad joined the medical register in the 12 months up to June 2019, compared to just over 8,100 in the preceding 12 months.

By contrast, The number of new starters trained in Britain remains static at around 7,100 each year, the new General Medical Council (GMC) report reveals.

The widening difference - now 28 per cent, up from 12 per cent the year before - has prompted calls to boost the number of home-grown doctors.

The surge is thought to be due partly to the removal in 2018 of an artificial cap on the number of foreign-trained doctors.

The trend is being predominantly fuelled by those coming from outside Europe, with South Asia the biggest contributor, although there has also been an increase in the number of European-trained doctors joining the UK workforce, three per cent since 2017.

Such a heavy reliance on foreign doctors is considered precarious for the long-term strength of the workforce because, historically, the NHS has a shaky record of retaining them.

Heavy workloads and insufficient efforts to help overseas staff acclimatise have been blamed for poor retention.
